author: .vbuterin
content:
> Is it really a good idea to transition to EC-based Verkle Tries right now given that Quantum Computing is progressing and may be used to attack the state in the future? Shouldn't we primarily look for purely hash-based alternatives? (or at least quantum-safe)

I think my answer to this is, stateless-to-stateless transition is significantly easier than stateful-to-stateless, and the verkle transition includes some key one-time changes (esp around gas costs), and those two facts together mean that, with the verkle tree transition done, the total complexity of a transition to ideal STARK-friendly binary merkle trees drops by ~4x

author: .vbuterin
content: So it's actually a perfect stepping stone

author: .vbuterin
content: btw I *have* seriously brought up the idea of dumping verkle trees last-minute and going straight to binary hash trees

author: .vbuterin
content: The argument against basically is: we would have to choose between either stark-friendly hashes, which are not cryptographically mature enough, or sha256, for which proving is too slow
